itemDescription: British Roman Catholic philanthropist; co-founder of Catholic Building Society.

wikipedia_page.main: The Honourable Nona Georgette Byrne DSG (10 September 1922 – 31 October 2012), née Nona Georgette Lawrence, was a British Roman Catholic philanthropist. In 1960, with her husband Vincent Byrne, she founded the Catholic Building Society, becoming the first woman to be elected chairman of a building society.

response: St Joseph's Hall in Greyfriars Lane is a Grade II listed  former residence of the Bishop of Arundel and Brighton. It was built as a private house for US businessman George Trotter in 1910, and then sold to a French religious order, the Norbertines. In 1956 it was used by Vincent and Nona Byrne as a home for refugees from the Hungarian uprising.

The Catholic Building Society was a UK building society based in Westminster, London. It was the 57th largest in the United Kingdom based on total assets of £44 million at 31 December 2007.Building Societies Association - Asset List (PDF File)  The Society was started by Vincent Byrne and the Hon. Nona Byrne, in 1960.
Vincent Byrne retired from the Society in 1967, remaining as Honorary President until his death, aged 70, in 1978. He was succeeded by the Duke of Norfolk and subsequently by Nona Byrne.
**Nona Byrne, 90, Building Society founder and philanthropist.
*Nona Byrne, 90, British Building Society founder and philanthropist.

link_mentions.page: Shrine Church of Our Lady of Consolation and St Francis
response: On 31 October 2012, the philanthropist Nona Byrne died. She was also buried in the church.
* Nona Byrne (1922–2012), British Roman Catholic philanthropist

St Joseph's Hall in Greyfriars Lane, Storrington, West Sussex is a Grade II listed  former residence of the Bishop of Arundel and Brighton. It was built as a private house for US businessman George Trotter in 1910, and then sold to a French religious order, the Norbertines. In 1956 it was used by Vincent and Nona Byrne as a home for refugees from the Hungarian uprising.
